title: 15 Essential DSA Patterns for Tech Interviews
content:
Hey everyone! Many of us struggle with DSA and feel overwhelmed during interview preparation. This might be because we try to solve every problem differently instead of recognizing patterns. However, if you break down DSA into clear patterns and master each one, interviews become much more manageable. So I've compiled the complete list of patterns you absolutely need to know!

---

##  Pattern 1: Sliding Window

**Why This Pattern Matters:**
Sliding window is one of the most frequently tested patterns in interviews. It optimizes brute force O(n²) solutions to O(n) by maintaining a window of elements and sliding it across the array/string. This pattern appears in substring problems, subarray problems, and anywhere you need to track a contiguous sequence.

**When to Use:**
- Finding longest/shortest substring with condition
- Subarray with target sum/property
- Maximum/minimum in subarrays of size K
- Problems with "contiguous" elements

**Key Technique:**
- Fixed window: Move right, slide left when window size exceeds K
- Variable window: Expand right, shrink left when condition violated

**Practice Problems:**
1. [Maximum Sum Subarray of Size K](https://leetcode.com/problems/maximum-average-subarray-i/)
2. [Longest Substring Without Repeating Characters](https://leetcode.com/problems/longest-substring-without-repeating-characters/)
3. [Minimum Window Substring](https://leetcode.com/problems/minimum-window-substring/)
4. [Longest Repeating Character Replacement](https://leetcode.com/problems/longest-repeating-character-replacement/)
5. [Permutation in String](https://leetcode.com/problems/permutation-in-string/)
6. [Find All Anagrams in a String](https://leetcode.com/problems/find-all-anagrams-in-a-string/)
7. [Fruit Into Baskets](https://leetcode.com/problems/fruit-into-baskets/)
8. [Longest Substring with At Most K Distinct Characters](https://leetcode.com/problems/longest-substring-with-at-most-k-distinct-characters/)

---

##  Pattern 2: Prefix Sum

**Why This Pattern Matters:**
Prefix sum is a preprocessing technique that allows you to calculate range sums in O(1) time. It's crucial for subarray sum problems and appears in many optimization scenarios. This pattern is often combined with hash maps for powerful solutions to sum-related problems.

**When to Use:**
- Subarray sum equals K
- Range sum queries
- Finding subarrays with specific properties
- 2D matrix sum queries

**Key Technique:**
```
prefixSum[i] = arr[0] + arr[1] + ... + arr[i]
sum(i, j) = prefixSum[j] - prefixSum[i-1]
```

**Practice Problems:**
1. [Subarray Sum Equals K](https://leetcode.com/problems/subarray-sum-equals-k/)
2. [Contiguous Array](https://leetcode.com/problems/contiguous-array/)
3. [Range Sum Query - Immutable](https://leetcode.com/problems/range-sum-query-immutable/)
4. [Range Sum Query 2D - Immutable](https://leetcode.com/problems/range-sum-query-2d-immutable/)
5. [Product of Array Except Self](https://leetcode.com/problems/product-of-array-except-self/)
6. [Find Pivot Index](https://leetcode.com/problems/find-pivot-index/)
7. [Subarray Sums Divisible by K](https://leetcode.com/problems/subarray-sums-divisible-by-k/)

---

##  Pattern 3: Two Pointers

**Why This Pattern Matters:**
Two pointers is your go-to technique for array/string problems that require comparing or processing elements from different positions. It reduces time complexity from O(n²) to O(n) in many cases. This is one of the most versatile patterns - works on sorted arrays, palindromes, and partitioning problems.

**When to Use:**
- Sorted array problems
- Palindrome checking
- Pair/triplet sum problems
- Removing duplicates
- Partitioning arrays

**Key Technique:**
- Opposite direction: Start from both ends, move toward center
- Same direction: Both pointers move forward at different speeds

**Practice Problems:**
1. [Two Sum II - Sorted Array](https://leetcode.com/problems/two-sum-ii-input-array-is-sorted/)
2. [3Sum](https://leetcode.com/problems/3sum/)
3. [Container With Most Water](https://leetcode.com/problems/container-with-most-water/)
4. [Valid Palindrome](https://leetcode.com/problems/valid-palindrome/)
5. [Remove Duplicates from Sorted Array](https://leetcode.com/problems/remove-duplicates-from-sorted-array/)
6. [Trapping Rain Water](https://leetcode.com/problems/trapping-rain-water/)
7. [Sort Colors](https://leetcode.com/problems/sort-colors/)

---

## Pattern 4: Fast & Slow Pointers

**Why This Pattern Matters:**
Fast and slow pointers (tortoise and hare) is an elegant technique for detecting cycles and finding middle elements in linked lists. It uses O(1) space where naive approaches need O(n). This pattern is a favorite in interviews because it tests your understanding of pointer manipulation.

**When to Use:**
- Cycle detection in linked lists
- Finding middle of linked list
- Finding cycle start point
- Happy number problems
- Palindrome linked list

**Key Technique:**
- Slow moves 1 step, fast moves 2 steps
- If cycle exists, they'll meet
- After meeting, reset one to head to find cycle start

**Practice Problems:**
1. [Linked List Cycle](https://leetcode.com/problems/linked-list-cycle/)
2. [Linked List Cycle II](https://leetcode.com/problems/linked-list-cycle-ii/)
3. [Middle of the Linked List](https://leetcode.com/problems/middle-of-the-linked-list/)
4. [Happy Number](https://leetcode.com/problems/happy-number/)
5. [Palindrome Linked List](https://leetcode.com/problems/palindrome-linked-list/)
6. [Reorder List](https://leetcode.com/problems/reorder-list/)

---

##  Pattern 5: LinkedList In-place Reversal

**Why This Pattern Matters:**
Reversing linked lists in-place is a fundamental skill that appears frequently in interviews. It requires careful pointer manipulation and tests your understanding of linked list structure. Once you master the basic reversal, variations become straightforward.

**When to Use:**
- Reverse entire linked list
- Reverse part of linked list
- Reverse in groups of K
- Reorder linked list

**Key Technique:**
```java
prev = null, curr = head
while (curr != null) {
    next = curr.next
    curr.next = prev
    prev = curr
    curr = next
}
```

**Practice Problems:**
1. [Reverse Linked List](https://leetcode.com/problems/reverse-linked-list/)
2. [Reverse Linked List II](https://leetcode.com/problems/reverse-linked-list-ii/)
3. [Reverse Nodes in k-Group](https://leetcode.com/problems/reverse-nodes-in-k-group/)
4. [Swap Nodes in Pairs](https://leetcode.com/problems/swap-nodes-in-pairs/)
5. [Reorder List](https://leetcode.com/problems/reorder-list/)
6. [Rotate List](https://leetcode.com/problems/rotate-list/)

---

##  Pattern 6: Monotonic Stack

**Why This Pattern Matters:**
Monotonic stack maintains elements in increasing or decreasing order, allowing you to find next/previous greater/smaller elements efficiently. This pattern transforms O(n²) brute force solutions into O(n). It's particularly elegant once you understand when to push and when to pop.

**When to Use:**
- Next greater/smaller element
- Previous greater/smaller element
- Histogram problems
- Temperature problems
- Stock span problems

**Key Technique:**
- Increasing stack: Pop when current > stack.top()
- Decreasing stack: Pop when current < stack.top()
- Store indices rather than values for more info

**Practice Problems:**
1. [Next Greater Element I](https://leetcode.com/problems/next-greater-element-i/)
2. [Next Greater Element II](https://leetcode.com/problems/next-greater-element-ii/)
3. [Daily Temperatures](https://leetcode.com/problems/daily-temperatures/)
4. [Largest Rectangle in Histogram](https://leetcode.com/problems/largest-rectangle-in-histogram/)
5. [Trapping Rain Water](https://leetcode.com/problems/trapping-rain-water/)
6. [Online Stock Span](https://leetcode.com/problems/online-stock-span/)
7. [Sum of Subarray Minimums](https://leetcode.com/problems/sum-of-subarray-minimums/)

---

##  Pattern 7: Top K Elements

**Why This Pattern Matters:**
Finding top K elements is extremely common in real-world applications and interviews. Using a heap of size K gives O(n log k) complexity, which is much better than sorting O(n log n) when K is small. This pattern appears in recommendation systems, analytics, and optimization problems.

**When to Use:**
- K largest/smallest elements
- K most frequent elements
- K closest points
- Median finding
- Merging K sorted lists

**Key Technique:**
- K largest → Use min heap of size K
- K smallest → Use max heap of size K
- Maintain heap size = K, replace root if better element found

**Practice Problems:**
1. [Kth Largest Element in an Array](https://leetcode.com/problems/kth-largest-element-in-an-array/)
2. [Top K Frequent Elements](https://leetcode.com/problems/top-k-frequent-elements/)
3. [K Closest Points to Origin](https://leetcode.com/problems/k-closest-points-to-origin/)
4. [Find Median from Data Stream](https://leetcode.com/problems/find-median-from-data-stream/)
5. [Merge K Sorted Lists](https://leetcode.com/problems/merge-k-sorted-lists/)
6. [Kth Smallest Element in a Sorted Matrix](https://leetcode.com/problems/kth-smallest-element-in-a-sorted-matrix/)

---

##  Pattern 8: Overlapping Intervals (Merge Intervals)

**Why This Pattern Matters:**
Interval problems are ubiquitous in scheduling, calendar, and resource allocation scenarios. The key insight is to sort intervals first, then merge/process in a single pass. This pattern appears in meeting rooms, flight bookings, and timeline problems.

**When to Use:**
- Merging intervals
- Finding overlapping intervals
- Interval insertion
- Meeting room problems
- Scheduling conflicts

**Key Technique:**
1. Sort intervals by start time
2. Iterate and check if current overlaps with previous
3. Merge or count as needed

**Practice Problems:**
1. [Merge Intervals](https://leetcode.com/problems/merge-intervals/)
2. [Insert Interval](https://leetcode.com/problems/insert-interval/)
3. [Non-overlapping Intervals](https://leetcode.com/problems/non-overlapping-intervals/)
4. [Meeting Rooms](https://leetcode.com/problems/meeting-rooms/)
5. [Meeting Rooms II](https://leetcode.com/problems/meeting-rooms-ii/)
6. [Minimum Number of Arrows to Burst Balloons](https://leetcode.com/problems/minimum-number-of-arrows-to-burst-balloons/)
7. [Car Pooling](https://leetcode.com/problems/car-pooling/)

---

##  Pattern 9: Modified Binary Search

**Why This Pattern Matters:**
Binary search isn't just for finding elements in sorted arrays. Modified binary search applies the same principle to rotated arrays, search space reduction, and optimization problems. Recognizing when a problem can use binary search on the "answer space" is a key skill.

**When to Use:**
- Rotated sorted arrays
- Peak finding
- Search in 2D matrix
- Finding square root
- Capacity optimization problems
- "Minimum/maximum value such that..."

**Key Technique:**
- Identify monotonic property
- Binary search on answer space
- Check feasibility in O(n) or less

**Practice Problems:**
1. [Binary Search](https://leetcode.com/problems/binary-search/)
2. [Search in Rotated Sorted Array](https://leetcode.com/problems/search-in-rotated-sorted-array/)
3. [Find Minimum in Rotated Sorted Array](https://leetcode.com/problems/find-minimum-in-rotated-sorted-array/)
4. [Search a 2D Matrix](https://leetcode.com/problems/search-a-2d-matrix/)
5. [Find Peak Element](https://leetcode.com/problems/find-peak-element/)
6. [Capacity To Ship Packages Within D Days](https://leetcode.com/problems/capacity-to-ship-packages-within-d-days/)
7. [Koko Eating Bananas](https://leetcode.com/problems/koko-eating-bananas/)

---

##  Pattern 10: Binary Tree Traversal

**Why This Pattern Matters:**
Tree traversal is fundamental to all tree problems. Understanding the three main traversals (inorder, preorder, postorder) and level-order traversal is essential. Each traversal has specific use cases - inorder for BST, preorder for copying, postorder for deletion, level-order for shortest path.

**When to Use:**
- Process all nodes in specific order
- Inorder: BST sorted order, validation
- Preorder: Tree serialization, copying
- Postorder: Tree deletion, dependency resolution
- Level-order: Shortest path, level-wise processing

**Key Technique:**
- DFS: Recursion or stack (inorder, preorder, postorder)
- BFS: Queue (level-order)

**Practice Problems:**
1. [Binary Tree Inorder Traversal](https://leetcode.com/problems/binary-tree-inorder-traversal/)
2. [Binary Tree Preorder Traversal](https://leetcode.com/problems/binary-tree-preorder-traversal/)
3. [Binary Tree Postorder Traversal](https://leetcode.com/problems/binary-tree-postorder-traversal/)
4. [Binary Tree Level Order Traversal](https://leetcode.com/problems/binary-tree-level-order-traversal/)
5. [Binary Tree Zigzag Level Order Traversal](https://leetcode.com/problems/binary-tree-zigzag-level-order-traversal/)
6. [Validate Binary Search Tree](https://leetcode.com/problems/validate-binary-search-tree/)

---

##  Pattern 11: Depth-First Search (DFS)

**Why This Pattern Matters:**
DFS explores as deep as possible before backtracking. It's your go-to for tree problems, graph cycle detection, path finding, and exploring all possibilities. DFS is particularly elegant with recursion and forms the basis for backtracking problems.

**When to Use:**
- Tree depth/height problems
- Path sum problems
- Cycle detection
- Connected components
- Topological sort
- Graph coloring

**Key Technique:**
- Mark visited
- Process current node
- Recursively visit neighbors
- Unmark if backtracking needed

**Practice Problems:**
1. [Maximum Depth of Binary Tree](https://leetcode.com/problems/maximum-depth-of-binary-tree/)
2. [Path Sum](https://leetcode.com/problems/path-sum/)
3. [Number of Islands](https://leetcode.com/problems/number-of-islands/)
4. [Clone Graph](https://leetcode.com/problems/clone-graph/)
5. [Course Schedule](https://leetcode.com/problems/course-schedule/)
6. [Pacific Atlantic Water Flow](https://leetcode.com/problems/pacific-atlantic-water-flow/)
7. [Longest Increasing Path in a Matrix](https://leetcode.com/problems/longest-increasing-path-in-a-matrix/)

---

##  Pattern 12: Breadth-First Search (BFS)

**Why This Pattern Matters:**
BFS explores level by level, guaranteeing shortest path in unweighted graphs. It's essential for level-order problems, shortest path problems, and minimum step problems. The queue-based implementation is intuitive and appears in many real-world scenarios like social networks and maze solving.

**When to Use:**
- Shortest path in unweighted graph
- Level-order traversal
- Minimum steps/moves problems
- Connected components
- "Nearest" problems

**Key Technique:**
- Use queue
- Add start node(s)
- Process level by level
- Track visited to avoid cycles

**Practice Problems:**
1. [Binary Tree Level Order Traversal](https://leetcode.com/problems/binary-tree-level-order-traversal/)
2. [Rotting Oranges](https://leetcode.com/problems/rotting-oranges/)
3. [01 Matrix](https://leetcode.com/problems/01-matrix/)
4. [Word Ladder](https://leetcode.com/problems/word-ladder/)
5. [Shortest Path in Binary Matrix](https://leetcode.com/problems/shortest-path-in-binary-matrix/)
6. [As Far from Land as Possible](https://leetcode.com/problems/as-far-from-land-as-possible/)

---

##  Pattern 13: Matrix Traversal

**Why This Pattern Matters:**
Matrix problems are just graph problems in disguise - each cell is a node, and adjacent cells are neighbors. Once you see this connection, grid problems become straightforward graph traversal. This pattern is extremely common in interviews and tests your ability to handle 2D arrays and boundary conditions.

**When to Use:**
- Island problems
- Flood fill
- Path finding in grid
- Region identification
- Any 2D grid problem

**Key Technique:**
- Treat as graph with 4 or 8 neighbors
- DFS or BFS from each unvisited cell
- Watch for boundaries

**Practice Problems:**
1. [Number of Islands](https://leetcode.com/problems/number-of-islands/)
2. [Max Area of Island](https://leetcode.com/problems/max-area-of-island/)
3. [Surrounded Regions](https://leetcode.com/problems/surrounded-regions/)
4. [Pacific Atlantic Water Flow](https://leetcode.com/problems/pacific-atlantic-water-flow/)
5. [Word Search](https://leetcode.com/problems/word-search/)
6. [Shortest Path in Binary Matrix](https://leetcode.com/problems/shortest-path-in-binary-matrix/)
7. [Number of Closed Islands](https://leetcode.com/problems/number-of-closed-islands/)

---

## Pattern 14: Backtracking

**Why This Pattern Matters:**
Backtracking explores all possible solutions by making choices, exploring consequences, and undoing choices if they don't work. It's essential for permutations, combinations, subsets, and constraint satisfaction problems. While potentially exponential, it's often the only way to solve certain problems.

**When to Use:**
- Generate all permutations/combinations
- Subset problems
- Sudoku, N-Queens
- String partitioning
- Path finding with constraints

**Key Technique:**
1. Make a choice
2. Explore with that choice (recurse)
3. Undo the choice (backtrack)
4. Try next choice

**Practice Problems:**
1. [Subsets](https://leetcode.com/problems/subsets/)
2. [Permutations](https://leetcode.com/problems/permutations/)
3. [Combination Sum](https://leetcode.com/problems/combination-sum/)
4. [Generate Parentheses](https://leetcode.com/problems/generate-parentheses/)
5. [Letter Combinations of a Phone Number](https://leetcode.com/problems/letter-combinations-of-a-phone-number/)
6. [Palindrome Partitioning](https://leetcode.com/problems/palindrome-partitioning/)
7. [N-Queens](https://leetcode.com/problems/n-queens/)
8. [Word Search](https://leetcode.com/problems/word-search/)

---

##  Pattern 15: Dynamic Programming

**Why This Pattern Matters:**
DP is the most feared but most rewarding pattern. It optimizes recursive solutions by storing results of subproblems. While there are many DP patterns (1D, 2D, LIS, LCS, knapsack), the key is recognizing overlapping subproblems and optimal substructure. Master the mindset, not just individual problems.

**When to Use:**
- Optimization problems (max/min)
- Counting problems
- Decision making problems
- Problems with overlapping subproblems
- Keywords: "maximum", "minimum", "longest", "count ways"

**Key Technique:**
1. Identify state variables
2. Write recurrence relation
3. Identify base cases
4. Memoize or build bottom-up

**Practice Problems:**
1. [Climbing Stairs](https://leetcode.com/problems/climbing-stairs/)
2. [House Robber](https://leetcode.com/problems/house-robber/)
3. [Longest Increasing Subsequence](https://leetcode.com/problems/longest-increasing-subsequence/)
4. [Longest Common Subsequence](https://leetcode.com/problems/longest-common-subsequence/)
5. [Coin Change](https://leetcode.com/problems/coin-change/)
6. [Edit Distance](https://leetcode.com/problems/edit-distance/)
7. [Partition Equal Subset Sum](https://leetcode.com/problems/partition-equal-subset-sum/)
8. [Unique Paths](https://leetcode.com/problems/unique-paths/)

title: Jr. Data Engineer Intern Interview Experience
content:
I applied for the Junior Data Engineer Intern position at BlueCopa via LinkedIn. After about a week, I received a shortlisting mail containing details about the position, location, and stipend.

The hiring process consisted of three rounds:

Resume Shortlisting

Online Assessment

Interview

Round 1: Online Assessment

Along with the shortlisting mail, I received an invite for the Online Assessment (OA), which had a duration of 1 hour 30 minutes.
I found this OA quite unique — it had around 6–8 modules comprising:

Python-related questions

SQL questions

Simple math and aptitude questions

English grammar

And some memory-based tasks (for example, a 3×3 block showing numbers that had to be memorized and later arranged in ascending and descending order).

I completed this round in about 70 minutes.

Round 2: Technical Interview

The next day, I received a mail stating that I had cleared the OA and was selected for the interview round. I scheduled my interview for 06-11-25, and to my surprise, the duration mentioned was only 30 minutes.

I reached out to a few current interns to get an idea of the interview process. They mentioned that the questions were mostly based on SQL, Python, and some basic coding problems like:

Fibonacci number

Reverse a linked list

Find the maximum and second maximum in an array

So, I felt confident that I could clear this round since it was supposed to last only 30 minutes.

Interview Experience

On the interview day, the interviewer began with his introduction and gave a brief overview of the company. After that, I introduced myself.

He started with OOPs concepts — asking about the four pillars of OOPs, the difference between overriding and overloading, abstract classes, interfaces, and the difference between them. I answered all of them with proper examples.

Then he moved on to SQL questions, which included:

GROUP BY

Different types of JOINs (in detail)

Difference between HAVING and WHERE

Indexing

Normalization

He also gave me a table and asked me to perform a few SQL operations on it.
By this time, more than 30 minutes had passed, and I was happy that I had answered everything well — assuming the interview was about to end.
However, the interview stretched to almost 2 hours 😅.

DSA Questions

He then moved to Data Structures and Algorithms, where he asked one easy and three medium-level problems:

Longest Consecutive Sequence

Reverse Words in a String

Valid Anagram

A variation of “Move Zeroes to End” (I couldn’t find the exact question on LeetCode, but it was slightly different from the standard one).

Project & Miscellaneous Questions

After that, he asked a few questions related to my projects.
By this time, I was mentally drained, and I couldn’t answer some questions properly. Also, I had mentioned in one of my projects that I “optimized it by 20%” and had “50+ active users” — which I had added just to improve my ATS score 😅. Unfortunately, that left a negative impression.

There were also a few Java-related questions, such as the difference between JDK and JRE, and one more OOPs-based question, which I couldn’t answer correctly.

title: My Guidewire Interview Experience — From Hope to Silence
content:
Hey everyone,
I wanted to share my recent interview journey with Guidewire — partly to vent, but mostly so others can relate and feel less alone if they’ve been through similar experiences.

I interviewed with Guidewire a few weeks back, and honestly, it was one of the most structured and technical processes I’ve ever been part of.

Here’s how it went:

1️⃣ Online Assessment (OA) – a solid round with problem-solving and coding questions.
2️⃣ DSA-based Round (taken by an engineer abroad) – focused deeply on system design and file system–based DSA problems.
3️⃣ DSA + Machine Coding Round (from Korea) – involved implementing a working solution with clean code, scalability, and edge cases in mind.
4️⃣ Onsite Rounds(one via video conferencing in office and other 1:1) (2 total) – included a technical manager round and a discussion with a senior manager from abroad. Both focused on my resume, design principles, and behavioral aspects.
5️⃣ Final Onsite Discussion – with a local manager, focusing on team fit, culture, and leadership aspects.

The offered range discussed was ₹19 LPA base + bonus — quite aligned with my expectations.

Here’s where the story takes a turn.

Before even completing my final rounds, the HR informed me that they were starting my background verification (BGV) process.
He clearly mentioned that it would only stop if something went wrong in the final round.
This made me feel confident that things were going well.

After the final round, I was asked to upload both sides of my Aadhaar card (I had initially uploaded only the front).
That communication came after the last interview — which to me, clearly meant I had cleared all rounds.

Then… silence.

I followed up multiple times — politely, professionally — and after several days, the HR finally replied that “the position is currently on hold, and we can’t proceed with your profile right now.”

That was it. No feedback, no closure, no proper communication — just a door closed quietly after weeks of effort and hope.

It hurts, honestly.
Not just because of the outcome, but because of how it was handled.
Throughout the process, there was consistent communication — until suddenly, there wasn’t.

I totally understand when companies have internal changes or hiring freezes — that’s normal.
But as candidates, we deserve transparency, closure, and respect for the time we invest.

I spent weeks preparing, giving rounds across time zones, interacting with teams from different countries — and then everything just vanished in a “position on hold” email.

I’m sharing this because this isn’t just about me — it’s something that happens to so many candidates silently.
Let’s normalize talking about it.

If you’re in the same boat — waiting endlessly after giving your best — please remember, your worth is not defined by a company’s silence.

#Guidewire #InterviewExperience #Transparency #HiringPractices #CandidateExperience #SoftwareEngineering #LowBalling #RespectCandidates #CareerJourney #TechInterviews #HonestHiring #JobSearch #EmotionalPost

title: My Vymo Interview Experience — Feeling Disappointed but Sharing for Awareness
content:
Hi everyone,
I just wanted to share something that’s been on my mind.
I have 2 YOE.
I recently interviewed with Vymo in September–October 2025. I was genuinely excited — the role matched my skills perfectly, and the process started off really smoothly.

The rounds went like this:
1️⃣ Online Assessment – 2 medium DSA questions
2️⃣ Machine Coding – Build a working Snake & Ladder game with extensibility
3️⃣ LLD + HLD – Design a Room Management System (schema + queries)
4️⃣ Managerial Round – Focused on my projects and problem-solving
5️⃣ Hiring Manager Round – General discussion about my work and goals

After every round, I got positive feedback. The HR even confirmed multiple times that I was selected and said they’d be offering 15–16 LPA (my current is 13 LPA, and I had mentioned an expectation of around 19 base).
I was okay with 15–16 and felt happy that all my effort was paying off.

Then the waiting started.
Days turned into weeks. I kept following up, and every time the HR said the offer was “under approval.”

Finally, after several follow-ups, she called back — and suddenly said the budget had changed, and they could only offer 9 + 1 LPA.
That’s way below my current salary.

It honestly broke my heart.
Not because of the number, but because of how things were handled.
I spent hours preparing, giving 5 rounds, getting told I was selected — and then, in the end, this.

I completely understand that companies have budget constraints, but transparency matters.
If compensation is a concern, it should be discussed upfront — not after the candidate has invested weeks of time and hope.

It’s sad to see how often this happens now.
We, as candidates, prepare sincerely, juggle our current work, and still give our best — and all we expect is fairness and honesty in return.

I’m sharing this not out of anger, but disappointment.
Because every time this happens, it quietly chips away at someone’s confidence.

If you’ve ever gone through something similar, you’re not alone.
Let’s keep supporting each other and keep pushing for more respectful hiring practices.

#InterviewExperience #Vymo #Transparency #Lowballing #JobSearch #RespectCandidates

title: Offer Dilemma — AI Startup vs Walmart (SDE III)
content:
Hey everyone,

I’ve got two offers and I’m struggling to decide which one to go with. I have 2.5 Years of experience. Would appreciate some honest takes from folks who’ve been in similar situations.

Option 1: AI Startup (early-stage)

Around 30 people, expanding, moderate revenue per employee.
Mostly remote with a few hybrid days. Work hours can be spread throughout the day.
Smaller team but quality people (mostly from Top indian colleges etc.), though I’d be among the most junior.
High ownership, more responsibility, and a steep learning curve.
Direct access to founders and leadership, more visibility.
Exposure to analytics and AI domain — good for future scope if AI continues to grow.
Risk is higher: if funding slows down, the company could shut down easily.
Experience may or may not hold value later depending on how the company performs.
Harder to get into AI startups in the future if domain expertise becomes a requirement.
Unclear long-term stability.

Option 2: Walmart (SDE III, Bangalore)

Large, well-established company with over 10k+ employees.
Stable, though global layoffs can happen during downturns.
Easier long-term brand recognition; MNCs tend to value Walmart profiles.
Exposure to large-scale distributed systems and complex architecture.
Easier to switch from MNC → startup later, but not the other way around.
Slower learning curve compared to a startup; work might be repetitive.
Less ownership and direct visibility due to multiple levels of hierarchy.
More people to interact with — good exposure to corporate culture and management practices.
Continuation in the e-commerce space; could build a strong career pattern there.


In short:

AI startup: High risk, fast growth, ownership, AI + analytics exposure.
Walmart: Stability, brand value, structured environment, large-scale systems.

I’m trying to decide whether to bet on the AI domain early, or go with a safer, brand-backed MNC path and switch to AI later if needed.


Would love to hear your thoughts and reasoning!!!

title: JPMC | JP Morgon | Cohort Hiring | SWE 3 | Selected
content:
All happened in October.
Compensation : 40 LPA Fixed

I applied to on of the positions on their Job portal.

# OA
Q1: Minimum operations to make the 2nd half of the string an anagram of the first half. swapping 1 character with another is 1 operation.
Q2: Given queries as [L,R], flip the sign of all the elements of array from L to R. Return the array at the end.

After this got call for cohort hiring and all 3 round will happen back to back.


# Coding+Code review round
Code Review a piece of code: There were a few APIs and you need to review it - check variable names, exception handling, using enums, reusing common code, synchronization and locking etc
Coding : Problem (telephone circular dial)

You have a circular dial with digits 0,1,2,...,9 arranged in that order around the circle. The dial’s pointer starts at 0. You are given a string s of digits (for example "8053") that you must dial in order.

You may rotate the pointer clockwise or counterclockwise. Moving the pointer by one position (to an adjacent digit) costs 1.

Optionally, pressing a digit might cost 1 (if the problem counts presses). I'll show both variants: rotation cost only and rotation + press cost.

Return the minimum total cost to input the whole string.


# HLD Round
Asked to design a Rate Limiter
Got into an agrument in this, during requirement i had said I will implement the sliding window counter method (which will be an approximation) as I dont think the rate limiting needs to be completele accurate.
But during designing that, she started saying read the question again (which didnt mention anyting strict as requirement) I said the same no such thing is mentioned and I explained already my assumptions during requirement, Anyway I said if we want it to be strict we will need a sliding window log method which will use memory.



# Behavior Round
Several questions regarding my project and how i handled this and that etc.


# Verdict
Never got an update after the interviews. and the HR never picked my call again. HR never shared his email and communication happened over jpmc system generated mails.

Update: I had received a call about 3 weeks later saying I have cleared the interview and someone will call for team matching round.
It has been another 3 weeks since that call. and there is no update!

title: rtCamp Interview Experience (Software Engineer ) 🧠
content:
# rtCamp Interview Experience | Software Engineer 🧠

**Date:** October 2025  
**Role:** Software Engineer / Full Stack Developer (PHP + JavaScript + React)  
**Experience Level:** Fresher  
**Mode:** Online  

---

![Screenshot 2025-10-30 at 3.52.56 PM.png](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/4cad40ba-2d99-4b46-8f21-0f870ead1e95_1761820317.9979508.png)

---

## 💰 Compensation Details
- **CTC:** ₹12 – 18 LPA (after confirmation)  
- **Internship Stipend:** ₹20K – ₹25K per month for the first 6 months  
- **Joining Bonus:** ₹1.5 Lakh after offer confirmation  
- **Post-confirmation Salary:** ₹1 Lakh/month  



## ⚙️ Hiring Process Overview
The rtCamp hiring process consisted of **two technical rounds** followed by **one HR round**.  
Each round focused on different aspects — from fundamentals and coding to design and real-world problem-solving.

---

## 🧩 Round 1 – Core Web Development & Fundamentals

This round focused on checking your understanding of **PHP, JavaScript, React, and Git**.  
It was a mix of conceptual and practical questions.

### 📘 Topics Covered
- **PHP – Hypertext Preprocessor**
  - Variables, arrays, functions, OOP concepts, sessions, cookies.  
  - `require` vs `include`, `GET` vs `POST`, form handling, API basics.

- **rtLearn Assignments**
  - Questions were asked based on your submissions in **rtLearn**.  
  - Be ready to explain your logic and approach.

- **PHP Basics**
  - CRUD logic, database queries, and API handling.

- **JavaScript + React**
  - JS: ES6, closures, promises, async/await, event loop.  
  - React: hooks, state vs props, conditional rendering, and component lifecycle.


- **Interview Discussion**
 Topics covered (asked in the interview):
Git and GitHub
System Design
System Security
Web Development

---

## 🧠 Round 2 – System Design & Problem Solving

This round tested **system design thinking, logic building, and scalability**.

### 🔹 Key Questions
1. **Design a YouTube-like video streaming platform**
   - Discussed architecture, CDN, caching, database schema, and API endpoints.

2. **Design a CAPTCHA system from scratch**
   - Image generation, random strings, session validation, and rate limiting.

3. **Elevator Algorithm (Lift System Design)**
   - Which data structure to use (Queue/Priority Queue)?  
   - How to optimize for multiple floor requests.

4. **Comic Service Problem**
   - You get 1 comic every 2 hours via email, but the server allows only one per day.  
   - How to handle scheduling, queuing, and caching?

5. **System Design – Load Balancer**
   - Concepts of reverse proxy, traffic distribution, and fault tolerance.

6. **Other Examples**
   - Chat app, URL shortener, distributed logging design.

---

## 💬 HR Round

- Background and motivation discussion.  
- Clarification on **internship + confirmation structure**:  
  - 6-month internship: ₹20K–₹25K/month  
  - Offer confirmation: ₹1.5 Lakh joining bonus  
  - Full-time: ₹1 Lakh/month  
- Checked communication, attitude, and alignment with rtCamp’s culture.

---



## 🧭 Tips for Future Candidates

- ✅ Complete your **rtLearn Assignments** carefully — many interview questions come from them.  
- ✅ Revise **PHP basics**, **React fundamentals**, and **Git workflows**.  
- ✅ Brush up **system design fundamentals** like caching, queues, and load balancing.  
- ✅ Focus on **explaining your reasoning clearly** — they value understanding over memorization.

---

## 💡 My Preparation Notes

https://youtu.be/I3uL-3gBFFc?si=jb5cbZRlwkL2P0mK

I compiled all the notes I used during my preparation — PHP, JS, React, Git, and system design topics are covered here.  
👉 **See my Notion notes here** : https://tinyurl.com/rtcampnote

---

## ⭐ Verdict

A really good interview experience overall!  
The questions were **practical**, **thought-driven**, and the interviewers were **very friendly**.  
If you’re into **open-source**, **web development**, and **real-world systems**, rtCamp is a fantastic place to start your career.

---

**Best of luck to everyone preparing! 🚀**

title: Groww SDE intern Interview Experience ( AI/LLM ) role | 6 month
content:
Hi all,
Just sharing my interview experience hope it helps someone preparing for Groww interviews! 

# How I got the opportunity 

I was referred by an employee at Groww and got the interview call directly after sharing my resume. All the rounds on same day.

# Round 1 — DSA (1 hour) 

The round focused on core data structures and algorithms, with two LeetCode easy–medium problems:

1.Single Element in an Array
2.Container With Most Water

I started with brute-force solutions, then walked through optimized approaches for both.
After solving, the interviewer briefly discussed my projects. Overall, the round went well.

# Round 2 — DSA + AI (1 hour, back-to-back)

The first half was a deep discussion around my AI/GenAI projects and understanding of LLMs — mainly to check my interest and knowledge.

In the second half, I was given a design-style problem, not typical DSA.
The task was to form pairs (3 girls and 2 boys) based on certain priorities, and I had to write pseudocode and explain my reasoning.

The round went fine overall.

# HR Round

An HR round was planned, but just before it started, I was informed that the feedback wasn’t positive, so it didn’t happen.


# Final Thoughts

Although I didn’t move forward, it was a great learning experience. My knowledge in AI/ML wasn’t very strong, that might have affected the feedback.

CTC - 20-24 LPA

title: Capgemini Interview Experience - 2025 Batch (Superset Drive)
content:
**Role(s) Offered:**

* Analyst
* Software Engineer
* Senior Analyst (for higher performance in rounds)

**CTC Range:** ₹3.8 LPA – ₹7.5 LPA (varies by role and performance)

---
🎯 Preparation Resources

▶️ Detailed YouTube Guide: https://youtu.be/oqjdjRMC2eo?si=qihoSX8dNHA1OxtO

📘 Capgemini Preparation Material : 🔗 https://tinyurl.com/capgeminiNotes

---



### **📍 Hiring Flow (Capgemini + Superset)**

1. **Online Assessment**

   * **Focus Areas:** Aptitude, English, Logical reasoning, and Puzzle-based questions
   * **Tip:** Practice logical games and time-based aptitude problems.

2. **Coding Round (if applicable)**

   * **Focus Areas:** Arrays, Strings, and Graph basics
   * **Platform:** Superset / CoCubes
   * **Difficulty:** Easy to Medium
   * **Examples:**

     * Find missing numbers in array
     * String reversal / pattern matching
     * Fibonacci, Prime numbers

3. **Communication Round**

   * **Focus Areas:** Clear and confident speech, pronunciation, tone, and fluency
   * **Tip:** Speak naturally; clarity is valued more than accent.

4. **Final Technical + HR Interview**

   * **Topics Asked:**

     * **Technical:** SQL/DBMS, OOPs, Basic coding logic (Fibonacci, palindrome, swapping)
     * **Project discussion:** Be ready to explain your project’s motivation and your role
     * **HR:** Basic behavioral and scenario-based questions
   * **Duration:** 20–30 mins

5. **Post-Interview**

   * Be patient — Capgemini’s interim offers and LoIs might take a few weeks to arrive.

---

### **🧠 My Tips**

* Focus more on **fundamentals** than complex DSA.
* Keep **communication round** serious — it’s eliminative.
* **Project clarity** is key for the final round.
* Stay calm, confident, and polite during HR.

---


**🧠 My Personal Tips**

- Don’t ignore the communication round — it’s a key eliminator.
- Revise DBMS + OOPs basics thoroughly.
- Have a solid explanation for your project — they often ask follow-up questions.
- Confidence and calm tone go a long way in interviews.

title: SDE 1 Spinny (Gurugram) | Backend Engineer
content:
Hey everyone 👋
I recently received a Backend Engineer offer (12 LPA) from Spinny, Gurugram, and wanted to share my interview experience — especially for folks from Tier 3 colleges looking to break into good product companies.

🧠 Background

🎓 College: Tier 3 (CSE)

💼 Experience: 1 year internship at a travel-tech company (worked on backend APIs, Spring Boot, AWS, Redis, SQL)

💰 Offer: Backend Engineer – 12 LPA (CTC)

🧩 Interview Process

👉 Round 1 – DSA (Tree-based questions)

Conducted by Interview Vector

Two medium-level coding problems, both on Tree data structures

Q1: Construct Binary Tree from Traversals

Q2: Lowest Common Ancestor / Boundary Traversal (type)

Time: 60 mins

Tip: Practice standard tree problems — recursion and iterative traversals

👉 Round 2 – System Design (Splitwise)

Asked to design Splitwise

Focus on:

Class design (User, Expense, Group)

How to calculate balances efficiently

Data consistency and scalability considerations

Also discussed REST API endpoints and DB schema

Tip: Focus on how you’d scale and handle concurrency

👉 Round 3 – Managerial Round (DSA + Discussion)

Asked to implement HashMap (core logic and collision handling)

Discussion around project ownership, debugging approach, and teamwork

Tip: Be ready to explain internal workings of collections

👉 Round 4 – VP Round (Project + SQL)

Deep dive into projects — architecture, challenges, impact

SQL questions on joins, aggregation, and optimizing queries

Also discussed cloud exposure (AWS, caching, monitoring)

🧰 Tech Stack Used

Java, Spring Boot, MySQL, Redis, AWS, JUnit, RestAssured

📚 Preparation Strategy

DSA: 150+ LeetCode problems (Trees, Graphs, DP)

System Design: Watched videos from CodeKarle, Gaurav Sen

Java Fundamentals: Collections, Multithreading, JVM basics

Projects: Focused on scalability & data flow explanation

💡 Key Takeaways

Tree questions are very common for backend interviews — revise traversals & recursion

Keep one strong project you can explain end-to-end

Be clear on how you design APIs and databases — even for small systems

Confidence & communication matter as much as coding

Let’s be real: you’re not being hired for the top-tier or impactful roles. There’s a big difference.

💼 Package for strong tech roles (worth being proud of):https://leetcode.com/discuss/post/7293936/oracle-mtsmember-of-technical-staff-fte-fn6k8/
👉 Oracle MTS (Member of Technical Staff) FTE : IC-1

⚠️ Package for lower-band roles: https://leetcode.com/discuss/post/7293922/oracle-associate-software-engineer-ase-i-a7k8/
👉 Oracle Associate Software Engineer (ASE) - IC-0

So please, stop being overly aggressive about “I got into Oracle” if it’s the lower band.
And remember — just because a senior is in that same role doesn’t mean it’s the right place or the right growth path for you.

I’ve seen quite a few from the 2024–25 batches in Oracle trying to show off like they’re in some top-notch role — but trust me, once you actually check their internal details on the people directory (Aria), the reality looks very different.

title: I Tried Beating LeetCode Like a Game. It Actually Worked.
content:
> Every wrong submission is just XP in disguise.

If you’ve ever opened LeetCode, stared at a “Medium” problem, and immediately felt like an imposter in your own career welcome, you’re home.

For the longest time, I treated LeetCode like a punishment.
Every night:

- Me: “One more question before bed.”
- Brain: “How about we stare at it until 3AM and still not solve it?”

After months of pretending that “Daily Challenges” were personality traits, I realized something most of us aren’t bad at LeetCode, we’re just training wrong.

So, I decided to turn LeetCode into a game, not a chore.
Here’s what changed everything.

## Level 1: Stop Grinding, Start Strategizing

I stopped doing random problems and started theme weeks:

 - Week 1: Arrays & Two Pointers (the gym warm-up of DSA)
 - Week 2: HashMaps & Sliding Window (where logic meets chaos)
 - Week 3: Trees (the moment your confidence collapses)

Each week, I did 5–7 problems of the same type until I could predict the pattern without crying.

## Level 2: Rename the Pain

I stopped calling them “Hard Problems” and renamed them “Boss Fights.”
It sounds dumb, but it’s psychology.
When I failed a problem, I just said, “Okay, the boss won this round.”
Next day? Rematch.

## Level 3: Learn Like a Developer, Not Like a Student

I started using a GitHub repo to store every solved problem not copy-pasted code, but my explanations.
Something like this:

- Problem: Two Sum
- Concept: HashMap lookup in O(n)
- Lesson: Never trust nested loops.


Now, every time I forgot something, I could review my own logic, not someone else’s YouTube tutorial.

## Level 4: Compete with Your Past Self

Instead of chasing ranks, I compared how long I took to solve similar problems.
At first: 40 minutes.
After two weeks: 12 minutes.
After a month: 8 minutes and mild emotional damage, but progress nonetheless.

## Level 5: Don’t Aim for 100 Problems. Aim for 10 That Stick.

Everyone loves saying “I solved 300 LeetCode problems.”
Cool flex.
But can you explain five of them from scratch without opening notes?
Mastering a few problems deeply helps more than speed-running 100 with no recall.

## What Happened After 30 Days

- My problem-solving confidence skyrocketed.
- Interviews started making more sense.
- And most importantly I no longer feared “Medium” tags like they were horoscopes of doom. 

LeetCode stopped being a torture device and became a skill gym.
You don’t need to love DSA.
You just need to trick your brain into thinking it’s playing a strategy game.

## TL;DR

LeetCode isn’t about brute force it’s about pattern recognition, smart review, and consistency.
So next time you open a problem and feel that existential dread?
Just remember: you’re not failing LeetCode. You’re just in the tutorial level.

# Your turn:
What about you?
What’s your weirdest or funniest LeetCode ritual?
Do you code with snacks by your side, rage-quit after two wrong submissions, or explain your logic out loud like you’re hosting a TED Talk in your room?

Drop your confession in the comments let’s make everyone feel a little less alone in this algorithm chaos.

title: Every Coder Needs This ONE Skill ?
content:
## The Most Underrated Skill Every Coder Needs — Patience 

Everyone talks about learning algorithms, mastering DSA, or writing clean code…
But no one talks about the one skill that actually decides how far you’ll go in coding — **Patience**.

### Here’s the Truth:

You won’t understand recursion the first time.
Your first DP problem will break your brain.
You’ll question your entire life during debugging. 
But those who stay calm, try again, and give it *one more shot* — they’re the ones who level up. Coding isn’t a sprint it’s a marathon and patience is the fuel that keeps you running.

If a problem feels impossible today → I take a break, then attack it again tomorrow. 99% of the time, it suddenly makes sense.

title: Not Syntax, Not DSA — THIS Is the Hardest Part About Coding
content:
## The Hardest Part About Coding No One Talks About 

Let’s be honest .The hardest part of coding isn’t syntax .It’s not DSA.It’s not even debugging at 2 AM. It’s that moment when you start doubting yourself. When you’ve been stuck for hours .When everyone around you seems smarter.When even a simple question makes you question your skills.
But here’s the truth, Every great developer you admire has been there frustrated, burnt out, ready to give up. What separates them isn’t talent it’s persistence.You don’t need to be a genius. You just need to show up again tomorrow. Because coding is 80% self-doubt and 20% breakthroughs but that 20% changes everything.

title: 💭 Taking the Hardest Step — Moving Away From My SDE Dream ,Bye Guys thanks once again...
content:
After years of grinding, giving my best in every contest, and facing countless rejections — today, I’m taking one of the hardest steps of my life.
I’ve decided to move away from my dream of becoming an SDE.
This decision wasn’t easy at all. I’ve lived this journey every single day —
1. Reached Knight on LeetCode without using a single copied code.
2. Participated in 70+ contests to reach that milestone.
3. Secured 1380 on Codeforces and 1670 on CodeChef.

I started all this because I truly loved mathematics and problem-solving. But lately, it’s been exhausting — the rejections, the bias, the randomness of interviews. Watching people who don’t even know the basics move ahead while your effort goes unnoticed… it’s painful.
But I’ve realized something important —
->I don’t want to stop my life in this dream.
Life is much more than just chasing one title or one job.

So, I’m choosing to start fresh — to explore what truly excites me, what gives me peace and purpose.
And to everyone reading this — especially those who didn’t get CSE and feel forced to compromise — remember:
-> A good college that gives you opportunities matters more than just the branch name.
This is a hard step, but it’s an honest one.
I’m done forcing myself into a dream that no longer feels mine.
Now it’s time to rebuild — in my own way, on my own terms. 
#HardDecisions #NewBeginnings #LeetCode #CodingJourney #Motivation #CareerShift #LifeLessons

title: Amazon SDE Internship (6m) (Jan - June' 26) (On Campus)
content:
**Eligible branches : CSE, ECE, EEE
Eligibility : No active backlogs and CGPA>=6.5**

**First Round : OA (70 mins)**

**Question 1** : You have an array of points (x, y) representing retailers' location. A retailer at (a, b) can serve to all points lying within the rectangle formed by the point (a,b) with both the axes. Given an array of queries, each containing a point, return an array counting the number of retailers that serve at the ith query point.

**Question 2**: Given an array of n integers, find the sum of different possible numbers that can be obtained as the difference of the highest and the second-highest elements of any subsequence of the given array.

This was followed by 2-3 untimed sections testing the behavioural and cultural fit.

After this round, around 38 students were shortlisted for the interviews. I, thankfully, was one of them. The interviews were held over a period of 2 days, 3 days from the date of the OA.

**Final Round : Technical Interview (60 mins)**

I was asked to introduce myself, which was followed by queestions regarding the summer internship I had pursued and some basic questions related to the field in which I had worked.

Next, the interviewer asked two questions :
Question 1 : Given a binary search tree, modify it so that the in-order traversal can return an array of the values of the nodes in non increasing order. 

I asked the interviewer a few questions to clarify the problem statement. One of them was, if we could flatten the tree into a list with all children to the left. He told me that, while it is indeed a solution, we are looking for something that resembles a binary tree more.

Question 2 : Given an array of product ids, you had to return the minimum length of a subarray that contains at least k distinct elements, along with the starting and ending index.

I was asked the TC and SC of both solutions.

Follow up questions included use cases of a BST in real life, some time complexities, indexing in SQL, etc.

We concluded the round with a few questions from my side and best wishes from the interviewer :)

I had also asked some other people, and most of them were asked the "Search in rotated sorted array", "Minimum coins" problems. Path Sum III, Word Ladder, Next Greater Element were some of the other problems that were asked.

Also, almost everyone else was asked only 2 DSA questions. No fundamentals or other topics were touched.

**Results:**
The results came the next day. 15 people were selected and 3 were waitlisted.

**Compensation :**
Stipend : INR 1,10,000/-
Relocation : 400 USD per month
Rs. 1100 meal card per month as well.

Hope this helps you in your preparation. All the best!

title: Accolite x Bounteous Interview Experience | Software Engineer (Bangalore) | 2.5+ Years Experience
content:
**Role: Software Engineer
Final Verdict: Offer ✅
Location: Bangalore**

**Round 1: Coding Test (Online Assessment)**

> The coding test was conducted on Accolite’s internal assessment platform.
To be honest, the platform was quite laggy and not very user-friendly, which made the test experience a bit frustrating.

- The coding question was similar to finding the Lowest Common Ancestor in a Binary Search Tree (BST).

- The tricky part was that we had to write JUnit test cases for our code as well. Because of the laggy interface, most of the time went into handling the platform rather than optimizing the code.

- There were also some MCQs, but I could attempt only a few due to time constraints.

*🧠 Tip: Focus on easy to easy–medium level DSA questions and get comfortable with JUnit test cases. Time management is key since the platform can be slow.*

---


**Round 2: Technical Interview**

- This round mainly focused on Java 8 and advanced Java concepts.

- The interviewer gave one coding problem and asked me to solve it strictly using Java 8 features (Streams, Lambdas, Optionals, etc.).

- The problem itself was not hard, but they wanted to see how effectively I could apply modern Java concepts.

- A few additional questions came from Multithreading and Spring Boot basics.

*🧩 Tip: Revise Streams API, Functional Interfaces, Collectors, and core Spring Boot annotations. They focus more on your coding approach than just the final output.*

---

**Round 3: Techno-Managerial Interview (Approx. 1.5 Hours)**

> This was the most detailed round of the entire process, and during this round, I got to know that the position was actually for Goldman Sachs as the client.

**First Half (Technical):**

- Deep dive into Spring Boot, Microservices, REST APIs, API Gateway, Deployment process, and CI/CD pipelines.

- Questions were scenario-based and tested how I would approach real-world issues like service failures, scalability, and versioning.

**Second Half (Managerial):**

- Detailed discussion on my current project, roles and responsibilities, and features I delivered.

- I was asked about story points assigned in the last sprint and how much I delivered on time.

- The focus was on accountability, communication, and ownership of work.

*🧠 Tip: Have a strong understanding of your project especially architecture, deployment flow, and your personal contributions.*

---

**Round 4: HR Discussion (Approx. 30 Minutes)**

> This was a very calm and straightforward discussion.

- Covered salary expectations, family background, and preferred work mode.

- We also talked about benefits and allowances, make sure you ask clearly about:

  - Joining bonus

  - Relocation allowance

  - Temporary stay/accommodation support

*💡 Tip: If you are expecting a 150%+ hike, prepare a clear justification for it, like your technical expertise, project ownership, or market standards.*

title: 🏆 LeetCode Ultimate Hack Sheet | Quick Reference for Everyone
content:
Hey friends 
I put together a **compact hack sheet** that’s useful for everyone from beginners to advanced coders. It covers key patterns, templates, and tips that **actually help in interviews & contests**.  

---

## 1️⃣ Problem Patterns & Templates

| Pattern | Common Problem Types | Quick Tip / Template |
|---------|-------------------|--------------------|
| **Two Pointers** | Sorted arrays, pairs, triplets, palindrome substring | Use Left & Right pointers → move based on condition |
| **Sliding Window** | Substrings, max/min sums, consecutive elements | Window can be fixed or dynamic → maintain count/frequency |
| **HashMap / Frequency Counting** | Subarray sum, duplicate detection | Track counts → check conditions quickly |
| **Prefix Sum** | Range sums, cumulative sums | `prefix[i] = prefix[i-1] + nums[i]` → get sum in O(1) |
| **Binary Search** | Search, insert position, rotated array | Set `low, high`, compute `mid = (low+high)//2` |
| **DFS / BFS** | Tree, Graph, Maze, Island problems | DFS → recursion/stack, BFS → queue |
| **Dynamic Programming** | Subsequence, knapsack, matrix, paths | Identify state, relation, base case → memoize results |
| **Backtracking** | Combinations, permutations | Choose / Not choose → build recursion tree |
| **Greedy** | Interval scheduling, max profit | Sort & pick the optimal choice at each step |

> **Tip:** Master one pattern → 90% of similar problems become much easier!

---

## 2️⃣ Top 50 Must-Do Problems

- **Array / Strings**: Two Sum, Trapping Rain Water, Subarray Sum Equals K, Longest Substring Without Repeating Characters  
- **Linked List**: Reverse Linked List, Merge Two Sorted Lists, Linked List Cycle  
- **Tree / Graph**: Maximum Depth of Binary Tree, Binary Tree Level Order, Number of Islands  
- **DP**: Climbing Stairs, Coin Change, Longest Increasing Subsequence, Minimum Path Sum  
- **Sliding Window / Two Pointers**: Minimum Window Substring, 3Sum, Container With Most Water  
- **Heap / Priority Queue**: Merge K Sorted Lists, Top K Frequent Elements  

> **Pro Tip:** Focus on **patterns**, not just problem titles.

---


## 3️⃣ Code Snippet Templates

**Binary Search**
```python
def binary_search(arr, target):
    low, high = 0, len(arr)-1
    while low <= high:
        mid = (low + high)//2
        if arr[mid] == target:
            return mid
        elif arr[mid] < target:
            low = mid + 1
        else:
            high = mid - 1
    return -1
```
**Sliding Window**
```python
left = 0
for right in range(len(nums)):
    while condition_not_met:
        left += 1

```
**DFS**
```python
def dfs(node):
    if not node: return
    dfs(node.left)
    dfs(node.right)

```
## 4️⃣ Common Tricks

- Modulus & Remainder → for cycles & wrapping arrays
- Sorting → simplifies Two-Pointer & Greedy problems
- HashMap → reduces nested loops, fast lookup
- Edge Cases First → empty array, single element, negative numbers
- Explain Aloud → helps retain patterns

## 5️⃣ Interview Mindset Hacks

- Patterns > Memorization
- Solve 1 problem in 2 ways → brute + optimized
- Use LeetCode Discuss for alternate solutions after attempting
- Track progress → Easy → Medium → Hard
- Time yourself → simulate interview conditions

💡 **Extra Hack:** Make your personal cheat sheet with patterns + go-to snippets + top 10 problems → for last-minute revision.

title: How Did You Start Your LeetCode Journey?

I’m **MS**, and I’ve recently started my journey with **LeetCode** and coding interview preparation. It’s been a mix of emotions  the excitement of solving a problem, the frustration of getting stuck for hours, and the confusion of not always knowing where to begin.

I know I’m not the only one who’s felt this way, so I wanted to start a discussion where both beginners and experienced coders can share what really helped them at the start of their journey. Whether it’s your daily routine, mindset, or specific resources, every bit of advice helps.

---

## 1. If You Could Give One Piece of Advice to Someone Just Starting Out, What Would It Be?

When you first began solving problems on LeetCode:  

- How did you overcome that initial feeling of not knowing where to start?  
- What’s your strategy when you’re stuck on a question for a long time? Do you check hints, read discussions, or revisit it later?  
- How many problems per week do you think is a good target for beginners?  
- Is there a recommended topic order to follow  for example, starting with Arrays and Strings before moving on to Two Pointers, Sliding Window, or Dynamic Programming?  
- Do you focus more on deeply understanding concepts (quality) or solving as many problems as possible (quantity)? How do you balance the two?

## 2. Best Free Resources for Absolute Beginners

I’d love to know what resources helped you the most when you were just starting out:  

- Any YouTube channels that explain problems in a beginner-friendly way?  
- Blogs or websites that helped you understand patterns or data structures better?  
- Any books or free courses that made key concepts finally click?  

Sometimes, even a single video or blog post can completely change how you approach problem-solving, so your suggestions could help a lot of people  including me.  

---
## 3. Your Biggest “Aha!” Moment

For those who have been solving problems for a while  was there a particular concept, technique, or problem that made everything start to make sense?  
Maybe something that helped you go from *“I’m lost”* to *“I get it now.”*  

Hearing about those moments can be really motivating for beginners who might be struggling right now.

title: From ₹10,000/month to ₹19 LPA — My Journey from UPSC Aspirant to Software Engineer
content:
I Graduated in 2022 from a tier-3 college. Like many others, I had big dreams but an unclear path. I gave 2 attempts at UPSC, even reached the **Mains stage in my first attempt**, but couldn’t make it further. By **mid-2023, I decided to switch to the IT field** — with absolutely zero background in coding or development.

I started with DSA from scratch. No shortcuts — just LeetCode, mentorship from college seniors, YouTube, and endless doubts. But reality hit hard — MNCs weren’t shortlisting me, and startups rejected me for having no dev experience. Every rejection chipped away at my confidence. I went through severe self-doubt and depression.

In **January 2024,** after hundreds of applications, I finally landed a small role earning **₹10,000 per month**. It wasn’t glamorous, but it was a start — and that’s what mattered the most at that time.

**Three months later,** I got a remote opportunity at an Australian startup with a **₹40,000 stipend**. That moment gave me a glimpse of hope — proof that my efforts were finally paying off. I took a short break afterward to recharge and refocus.

By November 2024, I started applying again — and this time, things were different. My skills had grown, my projects were better, and I had real confidence. I started getting calls from MNCs and top startups that once ignored me.

Finally, after multiple rejections and almost 10 months of continuous effort, in **September 2025** I cracked an offer for **₹19 LPA CTC(17 base) at a Bangalore-based B2B SaaS startup.**

**From ₹1.2 lack per annum to ₹1.25 lakh per month — that’s been my 1 year 9 month journey into IT sector.**

Was it luck? Maybe. I do believe God has been kind, but more importantly, it was patience, pain, and persistence that made it possible.

To anyone who’s struggling right now — don’t lose hope. Keep learning, keep building, and most importantly — keep believing.

Please share this with your friends who are preparing for UPSC.
Life is much bigger than a single exam — it always gives you more chances to prove yourself.
All you need to do is never let your hope die down. 🌻 

I’ll be taking another short break now, and this time, my focus is  to get into FAANG SDE2. Hoping to make it happen in 2026.
Cheers!

title: A Quick Thought on How We Give and Get Advice Here (Let's Help First!)
content:
Hi LeetCode family,

I love this community—it's one of the best resources for grinding, interviewing, and planning our careers. But I’ve noticed a small pattern that can make asking for help here really **frustrating**.

Someone posts a critical career question:

"I got an offer from Company X. Is the compensation competitive?"

"What's the WLB/culture like at Company Y?"

"Should I make this job switch for better growth?"

They're looking for guidance, and what's the typical first response?

"How did you apply?"

"Can you share your full interview experience?"

"What were the exact questions?"

The Problem
This immediately **derails the conversation**. The person seeking advice, in a moment where they need clarity most, ends up having their urgent career question sidelined by such requests.

The Solution: Let's Flip the Script
Context is absolutely important, but let's remember the priority.

When someone asks for career or offer advice, let's try to **lead with the guidance**:

**GIVE ADVICE**: Start with relevant info: "That comp sounds low for L5, I'd ask for X," or "The WLB is tough but the growth is unmatched."

**THEN ASK**: Follow up with a polite, non-demanding request: "If you have a moment, I'd love to hear about the process once you've had your questions answered!"

This small change shows **kindness** and **respect** for the person’s immediate need.

We’re all here to succeed. Let’s make this space less about extracting interview data and more about providing genuine, timely career **help**.

#leetcode #leetcodecommunity #request

title: Flipkart SDE - 1 , Boxes within Boxes..
content:
***There are N boxes which are 2D in shape. Each box has 2 dimensions, Height denoted by h and Width denoted by w.***

***A box can fit inside another box if the both the dimensions are strictly smaller. Mathematically, a box i can fit in box j if wi < wj and hi < hj.***

***A nesting sequence of K length is defined as a sequence of indices p1, p2,….., pk for some integer k ≥ 1 such that pi denotes the element positions from the original array, and the sequence follows the following conditions:***

*Solution :*

Always think this type of problems as 1Dimesional , so if we are given with an array [5,6,5,2,4,1], then if we need to do above like ai < aj , then we simply sort array and find inc subseq , using lowerbound .(LIS standard problem..) ..

But here we are given with 2D , Sort by width ascending, and height descending for same width , if we sort by width asecending , then one problem is not there like , we simply need to find LIS of width , which gives us answer , But what if 2 heights are same , we should not consider them , so we use height by descending such that it never happens. ..

This is same as https://leetcode.com/problems/russian-doll-envelopes/


Fr practice : https://leetcode.com/problems/maximum-length-of-pair-chain/description/

https://leetcode.com/problems/longest-increasing-subsequence/description/

title: Subarray Sum Queries - CSES
content:
There is an array consisting of n integers. Some values of the array will be updated, and after each update, your task is to report the maximum subarray sum in the array.

-> Brute force is to apply kadanes algo on everytime when we update the array..

Optimal Solution using segment trees >>

![image.png](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/75910965-43d8-466e-86fb-f7079c678496_1759226697.6682537.png)


So , we Initially build a segtree , with base case would be the element itself , and then starting from bottom we try to merge , on merging them , we need to careful about how we merge them ,

Suppose I am having left and right nodes , Now I need to update my parent , 

    parent.sum = left.sum + right.sum  //(direct)
    parent.prefixMax = max(left.prefixMax,left.sum + right.prefixMax)
    parent.suffixMax = max(right.suffixMax,right.sum + left.suffixMax)
    parent.maxSubArrSum = max({left.maxSubArrSum,right.maxSubArrSum,left.prefixMax + right.suffixMax})

How parent.prefixMax ??

We know that on merging 2 parts , it can be max of left or consider total left then add right max , simillarly for suffix..

title: Freecine Video Recommendation Engine | System Design
content:
# Problem Statement

Design and implement the core logic for a video recommendation engine used in [Freecine](https://frecine.com.br/).
![8fc07d86-16f6-4767-9c97-4e4cd498135c.png](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/0571b6b6-221b-4c20-9488-51ea4d7ed934_1759156124.547871.png)


The engine should suggest videos as the user interacts with the platform, based on previous watch history, popularity, and user preferences.

Given a search query or recently watched video, the engine should return top recommended titles (e.g., related movies, trending series, or popular APK content).

Recommendations should be ranked either by frequency of views or relevance to user interests.

We will use the strategy pattern to allow ranking logic based on different strategies.

# Implementation

User Context – each user has a history of watched videos, genres, and languages.

Recommendation Engine – fetches related videos from the library.

Ranking Strategies – based on frequency (most watched) or relevance (genre + language match).

Updating Usage – each time a video is played, its view count should be updated in the system.

# Entities

- VideoNode (data structure to store videos & traverse by category/genre)

- Context → language (e.g., English, Portuguese, Spanish) + genre (Action, Anime, Drama)

- VideoEntry → metadata and details about each video

- EntityType (Enum) → MOVIE, SERIES, ANIME, DOCUMENTARY, LIVE

- RankStrategy → rankVideos(List availableVideos, String query)

FrequencyBased

RelevanceBased

RecommendationEngine (Facade class)

# Entity Fields

- VideoNode

- children

- isEndOfVideo

- viewCount

- videoTitle

# entityType

- language

# Methods

- insertVideo(String videoTitle)

- findVideo(String videoTitle)

- getRecommendations(String prefix/query)

- deleteVideo()

# VideoEntry

- videoTitle

- entryType

- language

- viewCount

# RecommendationEngine

- VideoNode

- RankStrategy

- currentLanguage

- contextHistory

# Methods
- addVideo()

- recommend()

- recordView()

- initializeLanguage()

title: Sandvine  (Applogic networks)  | Feedback  🚩| Bangalore India |
content:
If you're a fresher, Sandvine might be worth considering to get your foot in the door. The pay (16–17 LPA CTC) is decent for 0–2 YOE folks, but don’t expect great learning or cutting-edge work. Treat it as a stepping stone—learn on your own and plan to move on after a year or two.

🎭 HR Tactics: HR will try to lowball and fear-monger. Be firm and negotiate hard. Don’t fall for the "great exposure & learning" pitch — it's mostly fluff.

🕒 WLB: Mixed bag. It’s not terrible, but not great either. Many folks regularly stay late. don’t expect a clear boundary between work and personal life.

**SKIP IT. THERE ARE FAR BETTER PLACES FOR SKILLED ENGINEERS.**

title: Stashfin SDE -1 Interview experience – Extremely Unprofessional
content:
My Interview Experience with Stashfin – Extremely Unprofessional 🚫

HR reached out to me for an SDE position. I confirmed my interest and was assured the process would move forward.

### 📝 Interview Rounds –

- I successfully cleared the first two rounds.

- Each round lasted about 1 hour 15 minutes, covering system design, DSA, CS fundamentals, and projects — requiring serious preparation and effort from my side.

### ⏳ 3rd Round Chaos –

 - The 3rd round (with the VP) was scheduled online, but I was left waiting in the meeting for 30 minutes, only to be told the VP was busy.

- This round was then rescheduled 4 times with no professionalism in communication.

- The following week, HR suddenly insisted I attend the 3rd round offline. When the online process itself was so mismanaged, on what basis could they expect candidates to adjust to such arbitrary last-minute changes?

### 🤦 Ghosting & Delays – 
For over a week, HR kept repeating that the VP was busy, leaving me in limbo despite the time I had already invested.

### 💔 Awful Ending –

### ⚠️ Final Thoughts –
 This experience reflects no professionalism, no hiring guidelines, and complete mismanagement. - Problem was from Alex Xu Vol.1 but with custom requirements.
- Covered end-to-end: requirements, design trade-offs, architecture diagram, and follow-ups.

**Round 3 – HLD + DSA (1.5 hrs)**

- First part: HLD again from Alex Xu Vol.1 with custom tweaks.
- Second part: Hard DP problem.
- Managed to solve both completely (all test cases passed).
- Felt good about this round.

**Round 4 – Hiring Manager Round**

- Mix of technical + behavioral.
- Deep dive into projects, past experience, some technical discussions, and situational questions.
- More conversational with a lot of back and forth.

Got a mail for document submission after Couple of Hrs. Shortly after couple of days, received the offer. Will update with offer details.

title: Infosys Interview Experience | Associate Consultant (Pune) | 2.5+ Years Experience
content:
# I recently interviewed for the Associate Consultant role at Infosys (Pune location) with 2.5+ years of IT experience. 
Here’s a breakdown of my interview journey:

**Round 1: Technical Interview (Virtual)**
- Focused on backend + Java concepts and practical implementation.

- Key questions asked:

    - Java 8 Stream API: use cases, filtering, mapping, grouping.

    - Microservices & API Gateway: communication patterns, advantages.

    - Spring Boot: exception handling (@ControllerAdvice vs @ExceptionHandler).

    - Coding Question: Find the K-th frequent element in an array (expected optimized solution).

**Round 2: Face-to-Face (Bhubaneswar Campus)**
- This was a detailed project discussion, I was asked to explain:

    - Features I had delivered.

    - My exact contribution in the team.

    - The business impact of the feature delivered.

The focus here was on depth of understanding + ownership.

**Round 3: Managerial Discussion (Same Day)**

Scenario-based and behavioral questions.

> “How would you handle a conflict within the team?”

They tested problem-solving mindset, leadership qualities, and consulting approach.

**Round 4: HR Discussion (After 2 Hours)**

Straightforward HR round.
Covered:
Salary discussion
Location preference (Pune)
Career growth & role expectations

**Final Verdict: Received the Offer for Associate Consultant role at Infosys (Pune).**

title: ❌ The Myth: “The more problems you solve, the better you get.”
content:
- It’s not about **quantity**, but about **quality**.
- What matters is **how you solve**, not just how many.
- Real progress depends on:
  - How you handle **hard problems**
  - When you choose to **take a hint** versus keep pushing
  - Knowing when to **surrender and learn**
  - How deeply you **analyze and understand the solution afterward**

---

## ✅ Then, How Should You Solve Problems?

- **Pick the Right Problem**  
  Start with something just outside your comfort zone. Don’t waste time farming “easy wins.”

- **Struggle First**  
  Spend focused time exploring approaches. Avoid jumping to the solution too early.

- **Use Hints Wisely**  
  Take a hint only when you’re truly stuck. Remember: hints should guide, not replace your effort.

- **Decide When to Stop**  
  If you’ve given serious effort but can’t progress, surrender and study the solution.  
  Don’t just read it — **study actively**.

- **Analyze the Solution**  
  Break it into steps and connect it with concepts you know.  
  Ask yourself: *why does this work?* and *why did my approach fail?*

- **Re-implement From Memory**  
  Solve it again later without looking. This cements the pattern in your brain.

- **Extract the Pattern**  
  Every problem teaches you a trick, an insight, or a reusable idea.  
  Write it down — this becomes your personal **playbook**.

---

👉 That’s how you turn each problem into **real learning**, instead of chasing numbers.

⬆️ If you found this helpful, don’t forget to **upvote**!

title: Don't join JioHotstar / JioStar / Hotstar
content:
Since the new Jio leadership took over, the company has become one of the worst places to work. The old leadership team was either fired outright, forced into situations where they had no choice but to resign, or quietly removed through silent layoffs that no one talks about but everyone feels. What’s left is an organization run like a lazy, outdated government office where politics and control matter more than performance or talent. 

Appraisals have been **dragged on for nearly a year now**, with HR shamelessly pushing the date every two months and feeding employees empty promises. Promotions are completely dead—there hasn’t been **a single one in over three years.** 

Morale is rock bottom, career growth is non-existent, and employees are left stuck in frustration with zero recognition for their efforts. The worst part is this new so-called “retention strategy”: deliberately withholding appraisal money and making people wait endlessly in the false hope of finally receiving it, instead of rewarding them fairly. 

To make matters worse, the leadership is more interested in outsourcing deals to companies owned by their friends so they can earn their personal commissions, while employees suffer with no growth, no rewards, and no future. The culture is toxic, manipulative, and soul-crushing, and staying here feels like a daily mistake. 

If you are thinking of joining, know this: you’re stepping into a trap where your career will stall, your work will go unnoticed, your ambitions will be crushed, and leadership will continue to enrich themselves while you’re left waiting for scraps.

3) The current allotted project is in the midst of migrating from the legacy tech stack to Spring Boot.
4) 3-day WFO hybrid culture, but it seems like they are moving to 5-day WFO from next year. Also, Walmart's policies seem to have changed drastically in the past.
